results.title: Connie Culp, First Face Transplant Recipient in U.S., Dies at 57
results.abstract: Her near-total face transplant in 2008 was the most complex at the time. She was the fourth patient in the world to undergo such a procedure.

multimedia.caption: Connie Culp at the Cleveland Clinic in 2009. She was the longest-living face transplant recipient in the world, a hospital official said.
Connie Culp at the Cleveland Clinic in 2009. She was the longest-living face transplant recipient in the world, a hospital official said.

results.title: Infections Swamp the U.S., Which Recorded 42% of All Its Coronavirus Cases in July
results.abstract: Thousands in Berlin protest Germany’s coronavirus measures. The virus is picking up speed in the Midwest. A summer camp in Georgia apologizes for hosting a retreat after hundreds who attended were infected.

results.title: Indian Billionaires Bet Big on Head Start in Coronavirus Vaccine Race
results.abstract: The world’s largest vaccine producer, the Serum Institute, announced a plan to make hundreds of millions of doses of an unproven inoculation. It’s a gamble with a huge upside. And huge risks.

multimedia.caption: Scientists at the Serum Institute in Pune, India, working on a bioreactor. Inside is a promising coronavirus vaccine candidate.

results.title: Can Humans Give Coronavirus to Bats, and Other Wildlife?
results.abstract: Federal agencies suggest caution in U.S. bat research to avoid transmitting the novel coronavirus to wildlife.

results.title: Overlooked No More: Roland Johnson, Who Fought to Shut Down Institutions for the Disabled
results.abstract: He survived 13 years of neglect and abuse, including sexual assault, at the notorious Pennhurst State School and Hospital outside Philadelphia before emerging as a champion for the disabled.

multimedia.caption: Roland Johnson in 1963. By speaking up about the horrors he endured at a state-run hospital for the disabled, he was at the forefront of an emerging self-advocacy movement.
Roland Johnson in 1963. By speaking up about the horrors he endured at a state-run hospital for the disabled, he was at the forefront of an emerging self-advocacy movement.

results.title: A $600-a-Week Lifeline for Unemployed Americans Expires After an Impasse in Washington
results.abstract: California became the first state to reach 500,000 total coronavirus cases. Once the site of a major outbreak, Italy now offers lessons for keeping the virus in check.

results.title: Gambling on College Football Almost Fixed My Dysfunctional Family
results.abstract: If Covid takes the football season away from us, we’re in danger of losing the bond we’ve taken so many years to build.

results.title: Weekly Health Quiz: Covid, Weight Gain and Intermittent Fasting
results.abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

results.title: In Indonesia, False Virus Cures Pushed by Those Who Should Know Better
results.abstract: In the absence of a unified message from the national government, local officials and opportunists have filled the gap with misinformation and quack remedies.

multimedia.caption: Muslims attending socially distanced Eid al-Adha prayers in Bandung, Indonesia, on Friday. The government has been inconsistent in its recommendations for combating the coronavirus.
Muslims attending socially distanced Eid al-Adha prayers in Bandung, Indonesia, on Friday. The government has been inconsistent in its recommendations for combating the coronavirus.

results.title: How Can I (Kindly) Tell People to Wear Masks in Public?
results.abstract: Our advice columnist tested a few possible lines. Here’s how that went.

results.title: Fauci to Testify Before Congress on Coronavirus Response
results.abstract: Federal U.S. jobless benefits are set to expire after lawmakers failed to make a deal. Herman Cain died after being hospitalized with the virus.

results.title: Johnson & Johnson’s Coronavirus Vaccine Protects Monkeys, Study Finds
results.abstract: It’s the second study in a week to report promising results in monkeys for a vaccine candidate. But the real test will come with human trials that are now underway.

multimedia.caption: Marinela Kirilova conducting research on the Johnson & Johnson coronavirus vaccine at the Center for Virology and Vaccine Research at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center in Boston.

results.title: As Covid Has Become a Red-State Problem, Too, Have Attitudes Changed?
results.abstract: There’s still a persistent partisan gap in the level of concern and in mask wearing.

results.title: Pandemic Loneliness in Late Life
results.abstract: Many seniors comply with the physical distancing and stay-at-home orders, even as we understand that social isolation generates the lethal byproducts of loneliness.

results.title: His Face, Hands and Feet Swelled Up. What Was Going On?
results.abstract: The young boy’s grandmother saw strange red lines snaking around his body. Could this be an allergic reaction? A rare autoimmune disease?

results.title: Old Vaccines May Stop the Coronavirus, Study Hints. Scientists Are Skeptical.
results.abstract: Certain vaccines may provide broad protection against infections. But new research doesn’t prove these vaccines can turn back the coronavirus, experts said.

multimedia.caption: A medical worker administering a flu vaccine to a woman in Asuncion, Paraguay. Some vaccines seem to protect against infections they were never intended to target.

results.title: Gum Disease Tied to Alzheimer’s Disease Risk
results.abstract: Severe gingivitis with tooth loss was associated with an increased risk of Alzheimer’s disease and other forms of dementia.

results.title: Renada McGuire, Resilient Home Health Aide, Dies at 39
results.abstract: She decided to work with adults with mental disabilities after giving birth to a child with challenges. She died of complications of the novel coronavirus.

multimedia.caption: Renada McGuire was a single mother of six who aided others in need of home health care while developing health problems of her own.

results.title: School Closures in the Spring Saved Lives, Study Asserts
results.abstract: But, experts caution, the findings highlight a period when few precautions were in place, and do not apply to current discussions about reopening schools.
results.byline: By Benedict Carey and Pam Belluck
org_facet: Journal of the American Medical Assn

results.title: Mysterious Coronavirus Outbreak Catches Vietnam by Surprise
results.abstract: After months without a single coronavirus death, or even a confirmed case of local transmission, a new outbreak has struck Vietnam. And it’s spreading.
results.byline: By Hannah Beech and Chau Doan

multimedia.caption: A street in Hanoi, Vietnam’s capital. People there are returning to the practice of wearing protective face masks with an alarming coronavirus outbreak.
A street in Hanoi, Vietnam’s capital. People there are returning to the practice of wearing protective face masks with an alarming coronavirus outbreak.

results.title: Judge Blocks Green Card Wealth Tests, Citing Pandemic Hardships
results.abstract: Deaths top 150,000 in the United States. A $600 unemployment benefit is likely to lapse on Friday, a top official said. In Iran, religious ceremonies and college-entrance exams are in limbo.

results.title: Is Your Blood Sugar Undermining Your Workouts?
results.abstract: Eating a diet high in sugar and processed foods could dent our long-term health in part by changing how well our bodies respond to exercise.

results.title: Why Is There No Consensus About Reopening Schools?
results.abstract: Here’s what we know: With too many variables and too few studies, schools lack the tools and data they need to balance education and health.

results.title: Moderna Vaccine Test in Monkeys Shows Promise
results.abstract: This coronavirus vaccine developed by government researchers and Moderna enabled the animals to quickly clear the infection from their lungs.
org_facet: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

results.title: The Coronavirus Could Dodge Some Treatments, Study Suggests
results.abstract: A laboratory experiment hints at some of the ways the virus might elude antibody treatments. Combining therapies could help, experts said.
